interactives.title: Area versus Applied Pressure
interactives.subtitle: Demo showing how the area (two-dimensional "volume") of a gas changes with changes in the force applied by a piston

interactives.title: Area versus Number of Atoms

interactives.title: Atom Data Table
interactives.subtitle: One way to display a table of atom properties.
about: There are three parts in this Interactive that work together to create the atom data table example.

1. Separate outputs are created for each datum to be represented in the table. The result is that the name values for these outputs can later be used for any component that can accept a model property.
2. numericOutput compnents are created for each of the output properties. All the numericOutput components are given the same width in 'ems'.
3. text components are created to make the row and column labels. The text components are given widths to match the rest of the values in that column.
The performance of this manual method for creating a table is not as high as if we made a custom table component.
atomToolTips are enabled in this Interactive, hover over an atom to display a tooltip, shift-click on an atom to make that tooltip persistent.

interactives.title: Atom Tracing
interactives.subtitle: Tracing and marking atoms.

interactives.title: Properties Transition
interactives.subtitle: Atom's properties can be smoothly changed over time using atomTransition() function

interactives.title: atomsWithinTriangle Demo
interactives.subtitle: Use atomsWithinTriangle() to select atoms within a triangle defined by its three vertices.
interactives.about: In this text interactive you should see a clear, triangular shape created by marked atoms.

interactives.title: Bar Graph Example
interactives.subtitle: Marking an atom and graphing it's kinetic energy.
about: There are 10 atoms in the model and the fifth one is both 'marked' and
it's kinetic energy is graphed in the bar graph.

interactives.title: callAt and callEvery Demo
interactives.subtitle: Use an callAt() to perform a script at any given time. Use callEvery() to perform a script repeatedly.
about: Changes in the model property: temperatureControl are monitored with an onPropertyChange() script.

interactives.title: Empty Model
interactives.subtitle: A model with no atoms can be both: loaded and run, and atoms can be added to it.

interactives.title: Interactive Components
interactives.subtitle: Examples of defining and using different Interactive components.

interactives.title: Interactive View and Model Options
interactives.subtitle: Overriding model and view properties in the Interactive.
about: This interactive presents how an author can overwrite model properties.
Take a look at the interactive JSON and **models** hash. There are two nested objects:
- viewOptions
- modelOptions
Compare values of _showVelocityVectors_ and _timeStep_ with the model JSON.
You will notice that values defined in these sections take precedence over
values in model JSON. Modify properties in these objects and click the
**Update Interactive** button to see changes.

interactives.title: Testing: Layout Example with html
interactives.subtitle: Current layout system does not support embedded html.

interactives.title: Markdown Demo
interactives.subtitle: Use markdown syntax to format content of text components and about dialogs.
about: *Markdown* can be also used in this dialog:

#Heading 1#
##Heading 2##
###Heading 3####
First paragraph. *Emphasis*.
Second paragraph. **Strong**.

Horizontal rule:
- - -

* An item in a bulleted list
    * A subitem, indented with 4 spaces
Inline image: ![Alt text](/resources/heatbath.gif "CC logo")
Inline [link](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax "Markdown Syntax") pointing to Markdown Syntax description.

about: Changes in the model property: temperatureControl are monitored with an onPropertyChange() script.

interactives.title: onSelect Demo
interactives.subtitle: Use onSelect() to attach an event handler function for select action.

interactives.title: Testing: Only One Atom
interactives.subtitle: The MD2D model works with just a single atom also.

interactives.title: Performance Tuning for Slow Computers
interactives.subtitle: Adjust timeStep and timeStepsPerTick to provide a better experience on your device.
about: See **[simulation-stepping](../../readme.html#md2d-simulation-stepping)** in readme for more details.

interactives.title: Pulldowns, radio buttons and custom parameters
interactives.subtitle: Testing property/value based pulldown and radio-button group using derived properties such as startingLength and startingAngle.

interactives.title: Testing: Pulling Uncharged Atoms
interactives.subtitle: Atoms can dragged to new positions, try pulling the red one a bit to the right and letting go. This model starts running when loaded.
about: These atoms are uncharged and have a Van der Waals attraction. Pull one a short distance
away and it will move back towards the other. However pull them far enough apart and they
won't move back together.

interactives.title: Remove Atoms and Bonds
interactives.subtitle: Both atoms and bonds can be removed with scripts.

interactives.title: Model integration time step, period, and sample rate
interactives.subtitle: Model parameters controlling the integration time step, period, and sample rate can be customized.
about: Try to change timeStep, timeStepsPerTick or modelSampleRate and observe changes in the speed of simulation execution.
See **[simulation-stepping](../../readme.html#md2d-simulation-stepping)** in readme for more details.

interactives.title: Simple Ball Drop
interactives.subtitle: Simple analog of a macroscopic ball dropped in a gravitational field

interactives.title: Simple KE Shading
interactives.subtitle: Kinetic Energy Shading can be turned on and off with scripts (and many other items also).

interactives.title: Vector Visualization
interactives.subtitle: Velocity and force vectors can be added to atoms and the display properties can be customized.

interactives.subtitle: Change viewport options to render different areas of the model

interactives.title: Simple Gas
interactives.subtitle: 19 uncharged and unbonded atoms.

interactives.title: Oil and Water
interactives.subtitle: 44 charged and uncharged bonded atoms displaying both bonds and VDW lines.

interactives.title: Temperature-Volume Relationship
interactives.subtitle: 57 uncharged and unbonded atoms interacting with an obstacle.

interactives.title: Hydrogen Bonds
interactives.subtitle: 17 molecules created from 51 atoms using 34 radial and 17 angular bonds and displaying VDW lines

interactives.title: 100 Charged Atoms, run 10s
interactives.subtitle: 100 charged unbonded atoms: benchmarking long-range pairwise (Coulomb) calculations. Run on page load for 10s.
about: This model has 100 charged atoms, this means that the modeling engine spends proportionally more time calculating pairwise forces for the long-range Coulomb forces than in some of the other models.
Since there are no bonds and no display of VDW lines the view is less computationaly intensive than other benchmarks.

interactives.title: 100 Charged Atoms
interactives.subtitle: 100 charged unbonded atoms: benchmarking long-range pairwise (Coulomb) calculations.
about: This model has 100 charged atoms, this means that the modeling engine spends proportionally more time calculating pairwise forces for the long-range Coulomb forces than in some of the other models.
Since there are no bonds and no display of VDW lines the view is less computationaly intensive than other benchmarks.

interactives.title: Phase Changes Caused by Energy Input
interactives.subtitle: 196 uncharged and unbonded atoms with about 400 VDW lines rendered.

interactives.title: Plastic Forces
interactives.subtitle: 252 uncharged atoms with bonds

interactives.title: Protein Folding
interactives.subtitle: How do peptides fold into stable conformations?
about: Explore the role of hydrophobic and hydrophilic interactions in protein folding. Generate a random peptide string and watch how it folds in an aqueous environment. Change the solvent to see what happens if the peptide is in an oily environment or a vacuum instead of an aqueous environment.

interactives.title: Amino Acids Momentum Test
about: A simple test checking whether the total momentum of each molecule (amino acids chain)
is always equal to zero.
Amino acids in water or oil are pushed toward the molecule center of mass or in the opposite
direction (it depends on the hydrophobicity of the amino acids). In most cases the sum of
these forces would be different from zero and would cause a confusing movement of the molecule.
They would drift and collide with boundaries.
To avoid this effect, Next Gen MW modifies velocities of each particle to ensure that the
total momentum of the whole molecule is always equal to zero.
That's why you can observe that each molecule holds its initial position.

interactives.title: Amino Acids
interactives.subtitle: A basic test of the proteins engine.
about: Using this interactive you can:
- change type of amino acids (right click on the amino acid to open a special context menu)
- test various coloring schemes and label types
- watch their behavior in vacuum, oil and water
- modify strength of the force produced by the solvent
- switch on or off _realistic dielectric effect_
- experiment with advanced proteins engine settings like additional solvent force or polar amino acids attraction

interactives.title: Custom Element Colors
interactives.subtitle: This model has a separate custom color defined for each of the four default elements.
interactives.about: The custom colors from left to right are: orange, light-blue, red, and yellow.

interactives.title: Dielectric Constant
about: An interactive presenting the dielectric effect and its influence on Coulomb forces. The graph plots two variables:
- distance between particles (in nanometers),
- **effective** value of the dielectric constant (*).
What does **effective** mean in the context of dielectric constant?
Next Gen MW uses a special algorithm for calculation of the dielectric effect.
When particles are close enough to each other, it assumes that the screening effect
of the solvent (oil or water) should be diminished. That's why you can observe that
the effective dielectric constant is significantly reduced when particles are closer
than 1.2nm to each other.
The effective dielectric constant for Coulomb interaction of two particles is
calculated using following equation:
**effectiveDC = 1 + (DC - 1)/(1 + exp(-12 * R + 7))**
where **DC** is an initial dielectric constant for solvent (e.g. 10 for water)
and **R** is the distance between particles.
You can disable this algorithm and leave the value of the dielectric constant
untouched (so, **effectiveDC = DC**) using the **Realistic Dielectric Effect** checkbox.
_Note that the effectiveDielectric output property defined in the interactive JSON does
**not** ask the model about the effective value, as it's unavailable in Scripting API
and hidden deeply in the engine internals. Instead, it recalculates effective dielectric
constant using the same algorithm like the engine._

Obstacle External Force
interactives.about: External force test: the obstacle should reach an atom after ~5 000 fs when default setup is used.

interactives.title: Point Restraints

interactives.title: Text Box in Center (imported from MML)

interactives.title: Text Boxes (imported from MML)
interactives.subtitle: Examples showing textBoxes imported from MML.

interactives.title: Text Boxes on Atoms
interactives.subtitle: Examples of different styles and positioning of text boxes attached to atoms.

interactives.title: Text Boxes
interactives.subtitle: Examples of different styles and positioning of text boxes.

interactives.title: Select one of Two Models using Pulldown Menu
Visible and Invisible Atoms
interactives.subtitle: There are four large invisible atoms near the center. These also participate in the molecular dynamics model.
about: This model defines 8 atoms. There are four larger yellow atoms initially defined as invisible closer to the center. These are surrounded by four smaller purple atoms further away from the center.
After starting the model the smaller purple atoms will start showing visible attractions with the invisible atoms at 7900 fs.
You can enable or disable visibility of the larger yellow atoms using the pull-down menu selection

interactives.title: Geniverse Gene to Protein
about: Geniverse Gene to Protein Genie

interactives.title: Pendulum
interactives.subtitle: Explore some factors that affect the period of a pendulum.
about: Press the play button. Watch the graph to see how the angle of the pendulum changes as it
swings back and forth. Use the graph to determine the period of the pendulum. Adjust the
scale by dragging the numbers on the axes. Change each variable – gravity, rod length,
starting angle and mass – and observe how each one affects the period. Can you explain why?
Try the damping slider. Does damping change the period?

interactives.title: Spring and Mass
interactives.subtitle: Explore some factors that affect the period of a spring.
about: Press the play button. Watch the graph to see how the height of the mass changes as
it moves up and down. Use the graph to determine the period of the mass-spring system.
Adjust the scale by dragging the numbers on the axes. Change each variable – gravity,
spring constant, starting distance and mass – and observe how each one affects the period.
Can you explain why? Is this different from the relationships for a pendulum? Try the
damping slider. Does damping change the period?

interactives.title: Pendulum and Spring
interactives.subtitle: Explore the motion of a pendulum on a spring.
about: Press the play button. Watch the graphs to see the motion of the spring pendulum.
Can you distinguish the pattern of spring motion (up and down) from the pattern
of pendulum motion (back and forth)? How are the two related? Is there a regular
pattern to the motion? Compare the periods of the two graphs. How many different
patterns can you produce by changing the variables – gravity, rod length, mass and
spring constant? Under what conditions does the energy switch between back and forth
and up and down? Does the initial starting angle affect the patterns when all the
other variables are unchanged?

interactives.title: Custom Component Dimensions
interactives.subtitle: Graph, Bar Graph, Slider, Button and Text can have custom dimensions specified using 'width' and 'height' properties (all CSS values are accepted).

interactives.title: Replacing Bitmap Images with SVG
interactives.subtitle: Experiments replacing bitmap images with SVG documents to preserve quality when scaled up.
about: This Interactive displays an image with a suggestion for how to start using the Interactive.
Current possible images including the SVG replacements for the png image:
1. [instructionBox.png](../../imports/legacy-mw-content/converted/layout-tests/svg-images/instructionBox.png)
This is a 253x58 pixel png image. Will appear pixelated when scaled to larger sizes.
2. [instructionBox.svg](../../imports/legacy-mw-content/converted/layout-tests/svg-images/instructionBox.svg)
Created with Adobe Illustrator this SVG image uses an embedded base64 image for the drop-shadow effect.
Additionally explicit paths are used to draw the text instead of using SVG text objects, this makes the text
rendering independent of whether a specific font is installed on the users computer.
3. [instructionBox2.svg](../../imports/legacy-mw-content/converted//layout-tests/svg-images/instructionBox2.svg)
Created using the open-source Inkscape application this SVG image uses SVG text elements and does not have a drop shadow.
4. [instructionBox3.svg](../../imports/legacy-mw-content/converted//layout-tests/svg-images/instructionBox3.svg)
Created by hand, this SVG image uses SVG text elements and the SVG feGaussianBlur filter to create the drop-shadow effect.

interactives.title: DNA to Protein
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the code embedded in DNA is translated into a protein.
about: Click **Transcribe** to zoom into the cell nucleus and see the chromosome unravel to expose the strands of DNA. The DNA separates and an mRNA strand is created by matching complementary nucleotides.

Click **Translate** to watch the mRNA leave the nucleus for the cytoplasm and attach to a ribosome. tRNA molecules bring in amino acids and the amino acids are added in the correct order by matching complementary nucleotides.
After translation, inspect the protein to see how the amino acid sequence folded.

interactives.title: Modeling Transcription
interactives.subtitle: Explore how an mRNA copy is made of DNA.
about: One strand of the DNA is used as a template to create an mRNA copy. This process is called transcription. An mRNA copy needs to be made because DNA cannot leave the nucleus.
Protein complexes separate the DNA helix to allow complementary mRNA nucleotides to bind to the DNA sequence. The pairing of nucleotides is very specific.
Use the **A**, **U**, **G** and **C** buttons to place the correct mRNA nucleotide with each DNA nucleotide.

interactives.title: Modeling Translation
interactives.subtitle: Explore how a protein is made from an mRNA sequence.
about: Translation, or making a protein from an mRNA sequence, occurs on ribosomes. The amino acids are brought to the ribosome by transfer RNAs (tRNAs).
The tRNA pairs up with the mRNA by matching up complementary nucleotides. This ensures that the correct amino acid is added to the protein.
Can you identify what the tRNA codon will be for each triplet of mRNA nucleotides?

interactives.title: Mutations
interactives.subtitle: Explore how changing the DNA sequence can change the amino acid sequence of a protein.
about: Mutations are mistakes in the DNA sequence. Use the **Edit DNA** button to change the entire sequence or click on an individual nucleotide to make an insertion, deletion or substitution mutation. How does changing the DNA sequence change the resulting protein?
You can quickly jump between the DNA sequence and final protein by using the **Show DNA** and **Show protein** buttons.
Are some types of mutations more damaging than others?

interactives.title: Diffusion of a Drop
interactives.subtitle: Add a drop of dye anywhere in the container, and watch it diffuse through the water.
about: Click in the model to add a drop of dye.  Watch how the molecules move through the water.
Trace an individual molecule to see how it moves through the liquid.

interactives.title: Basic Diffusion
interactives.subtitle: Watch a drop of dye spreading out in water.
about: Add a drop of dye to the model.  Watch how the molecules move through the water.
Trace a random individual molecule to see how it moves through the liquid.

interactives.title: Diffusion & Temperature
interactives.subtitle: How does temperature affect the rate of diffusion?
interactives.about: Explore the role of temperature on the rate of diffusion. Set the temperature, then remove the barrier, and measure the amount of time it takes the blue molecules to reach the gas sensor. When the gas sensor has detected three blue molecules, it will stop the experiment. Compare the diffusion rates at low, medium and high temperatures. Trace an individual molecule to see the path it takes.

interactives.title: Diffusion & Molecular Mass
interactives.subtitle: How does molecular mass affect the rate of diffusion?
interactives.about: Explore the role of molecular mass on the rate of diffusion. Select the mass of the molecules behind the barrier. Remove the barrier, and measure the amount of time it takes the molecules to reach the gas sensor. When the gas sensor has detected three molecules, it will stop the experiment. Compare the diffusion rates of the lightest, heavier and heaviest molecules. Trace an individual molecule to see the path it takes.

interactives.title: Diffusion Across Semipermeable Membranes
interactives.subtitle: How does pore size affect the diffusion of different molecules?
interactives.about: Biological membranes are selectively permeable; some molecules can cross while others cannot. One way to affect this is through pore size. Change the pore size with the slider to change the permeability of the membranes to the different types of molecules. Trace an individual molecule to see the path it takes.

interactives.title: Diffusion Across a Semipermeable Membrane
interactives.subtitle: How does pore size affect the diffusion of different molecules?
interactives.about: Biological membranes are selectively permeable; some molecules can cross while others cannot. One way to affect this is through pore size. Change the pore size with the slider to change the permeability of the membrane to the different types of molecules. Trace an individual molecule to see the path it takes.

interactives.title: Diffusion Across a Permeable Membrane
about: Oxygen and Carbon Dioxide can both easily cross this gas permeable membrane.
Change the starting concentrations of the gases on either side and observe how long it takes for the gases to diffuse across the membrane.

interactives.title: Diffusion - Build your own model
interactives.subtitle: Explore how size and number of particles affect diffusion among gases.
interactives.about: Modify the model by adding and arranging molecules in order to explore how diffusion works.

interactives.title: Diffusion Sandbox
interactives.subtitle: Explore how size and number of particles affect diffusion among gases.
interactives.about: Modify the model by adding and arranging molecules in order to explore how diffusion works.

interactives.title: What is Pressure?
interactives.subtitle: Explore how gas exerts pressure on the sides of a container.
about: Gases have no definite shape or volume. When they are constrained to a container,
we can measure the pressure they exert on the container walls.
The model shows the inside (yellow atoms) and outside (green atoms) of a balloon.
The teal barrier represents the wall of the balloon.
Add atoms to the balloon. Watch what happens.

interactives.title: The Volume-Pressure Relationship
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the volume of a gas affects pressure.
about: Gases can be compressed into smaller volumes. How does compressing a gas affect its pressure?
Run the model, then change the volume of the containers and observe the change in pressure.
The moving wall converts the effect of molecular collisions into pressure and acts as a pressure gauge.
What happens to the pressure when the volume changes?
*Note: Although the atoms in this model are in a flat plane, volume is calculated using 0.1 nm as the depth of the container.*

interactives.title: The Temperature-Volume Relationship
interactives.subtitle: Investigate the relationship between temperature and the volume of a gas.
about: This model contains gas molecules on the left side and a barrier that moves when the
volume of gas expands or contracts, keeping the pressure constant. Run the model and
change the temperature. Why does the barrier move when the temperature changes?
*Note: Although the atoms in this model are in a flat plane, volume is calculated using 0.1 nm as the depth of the container.*

interactives.title: The Temperature-Pressure Relationship
interactives.subtitle: Consider how temperature affects the pressure exerted by a gas.
interactives.about: Run the model and change the temperature. What happens to the pressure when the temperature changes?

interactives.title: The Number-Volume Relationship
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the volume of a gas is related to the number of gas molecules.
about: The model contains gas molecules under constant pressure. The barrier moves when the
volume of gas expands or contracts. Run the model and select different numbers of
molecules from the drop-down menu. What is the relationship between the number of
molecules and the volume of a gas?
*Note: Although the atoms in this model are in a flat plane, volume is calculated using 0.1 nm as the depth of the container.*

interactives.title: Pressure Equilibrium
interactives.subtitle: Explore how heat and number of molecules affect pressure equilibrium between two gases.
about: There are gases on both sides of a moveable barrier (piston), which stays in the same place
(more or less) when you run the model because the gas pressure on the piston is in equilibrium.
Add purple gas molecules and watch what happens to the piston. Reset the model. Now add
yellow gas molecules. What happens to the piston?
Try heating or cooling the gas molecules. Explain the change in equilibrium with each
change. Which has a greater effect on equilibrium -- changing the number of gas molecules
or changing the temperature? Why?

interactives.title: Collapsing Soda Can
interactives.subtitle: Explore how heat and number of molecules affect pressure equilibrium between two gases.
about: The model is an incomplete model of a soda can.
Currently it is showing gas molecules inside and outside the soda can before it is plunged in ice water.
The rectangle in the middle of the model represents a micro-section of the soda can wall.
Design a model that shows what happens after the can is placed in ice water.
Use the tools on the sides of the model to more accurately represent the experiment.
Use tools to heat and cool the molecules where it is appropriate.

interactives.title: Seeing Intermolecular Attractions
interactives.subtitle: A very simple interactive with polar molecules on the left and non-polar molecules on the right.
about: All matter is attracted to all other matter. How does this work?
This interactive shows polar molecules (with charges) and non-polar molecules in a
container with each other. Drag molecules around to see how they are attracted to
each other. Dotted lines indicate intermolecular attractions.

interactives.title: Comparing Dipole-Dipole to London Dispersion
interactives.subtitle: Explore the difference in attractive forces between polar and non-polar molecules.
about: Explore the different strengths of dipole-dipole (polar) and London dispersion (non-polar)
attractions. These intermolecular attractions are shown by dotted lines between the pairs of molecules.
Choose a pair of molecules from the drop-down menu and "pull" on the star to separate the
molecules. Which type of intermolecular attraction is strongest?

interactives.title: Oil and Water
interactives.subtitle: Explore how polar and non-polar substances interact.
about: It is well known that "oil and water don’t mix." But why? Run the model
of polar water (blue and red) and non-polar oil (gray). "Shake up the oil and water mixture,"
then run it again and watch what happens to the molecules over time.

interactives.title: Boiling Point
interactives.subtitle: Explore what boiling looks like at the molecular level with both polar and non-polar substances.
about: Non-polar molecules (gray) evaporate or boil more quickly than polar molecules (blue and red).
Attractions between molecules are shown with dotted lines. Run the model, then heat the liquids.
What does boiling look like at the molecular level?

interactives.title: Polarity and Attractive Strength
interactives.subtitle: Explore the different attractive forces between molecules of varying polarity.
about: Attractions between polar molecules vary. Choose a pair of molecules from the drop-down
menu and "pull" on the star to separate the molecules. Why does polarity have an effect
on the strength of attraction between molecules?

interactives.title: Factors Affecting London Dispersion Attractions
interactives.subtitle: Explore how differences in molecular size and shape affect the strength of London dispersion attractions.
about: Some non-polar molecules have stronger attractions than others. Choose a pair of
molecules from the drop-down menu and "pull" on the star to separate the molecules.
Why do size and shape affect the strength of attraction between two non-polar molecules?

interactives.title: Hydrogen Bonds: A Special Type of Attraction
interactives.subtitle: Explore how polar molecules interact via hydrogen bonds.
about: Explore hydrogen bonds forming between polar molecules, such as water. Hydrogen bonds are shown with dotted lines.
Show partial charges and run the model. Where do hydrogen bonds form? Try changing the temperature
of the model. How does the pattern of hydrogen bonding explain the lattice that makes up ice crystals?

interactives.title: States of Matter
interactives.subtitle: Explore Coulomb and Intermolecular Attractions
about: What kinds of patterns tend to form? How does changing the Van der Waals
attraction affect the melting and boiling point of the substance?

interactives.title: Blackbody Heat and Emission
interactives.subtitle: Blackbody radiation at different temperatures

interactives.title: Light Matter Feature Test
interactives.subtitle: Testing of Light-Matter model features

interactives.title: Sunlight, Infrared, CO2 and the Ground
interactives.subtitle: Explore how light interacts with both the ground and CO2

interactives.title: Molecular View of a Gas
interactives.subtitle: Explore how molecules in a gas move relative to each other.
about: Molecules are in constant motion. "Mark two atoms," then run the model to see
how the molecules move relative to each other. How do the distances between gas
molecules change over time?

interactives.title: Molecular View of a Liquid
interactives.subtitle: Explore how molecules in a liquid move.
about: Molecules are in constant motion. "Mark two atoms," then run the model to see
how the molecules in a liquid move relative to each other. How does the movement
of molecules explain why liquids take the shape of their containers?

interactives.title: Molecular View of a Solid
interactives.subtitle: What does a solid look like at the molecular level?
about: Molecules are in constant motion—even those in a solid! "Mark two atoms," then
run the model to see how the molecules in a solid move relative to each other. How
would you describe the movement and arrangement of molecules in a solid?

interactives.title: Intermolecular Attractions and States of Matter
interactives.subtitle: Explore how states of matter are related to the strength of intermolecular attractions.
about: There are three states of matter—solid, liquid and gas. Run the model and change the
strength of attractions between the molecules. How does changing the force of attraction
between molecules affect the state of that material?

interactives.title: Phase Changes with two bar graphs
interactives.subtitle: Explore how energy input causes matter to change states.
about: Matter exists as solids, liquids and gases, and can change state between these.
The model shows a liquid material on the left (small atoms). The amount of heat
energy is shown by kinetic energy (KE) shading, with deeper shades of red
representing more energetic atoms. On the right side of the barrier is a solid
material (large atoms).
Run the model. How much energy is able to penetrate the barrier? Remove the barrier.
How quickly do the more energetic atoms melt the solid?

interactives.title: Phase Changes
interactives.subtitle: Explore how energy input causes matter to change states.
about: Matter exists as solids, liquids and gases, and can change state between these.
The model shows a liquid material on the left (small atoms). The amount of heat
energy is shown by kinetic energy (KE) shading, with deeper shades of red
representing more energetic atoms. On the right side of the barrier is a solid
material (large atoms).
Run the model. How much energy is able to penetrate the barrier? Remove the barrier.
How quickly do the more energetic atoms melt the solid?

interactives.title: Oil and Water
interactives.subtitle: Explore how polar and non-polar substances interact.
about: It is well known that "oil and water don’t mix." But why? Run the model of
polar water (blue and red) and non-polar oil (gray). "Shake up the oil and water
mixture," then run it again and watch what happens to the molecules over time.

interactives.title: Charged and Neutral Atoms
interactives.subtitle: Explore Coulomb and intermolecular attractions.
about: There are two kinds of attractive forces shown in this model: Coulomb forces (the attraction between ions)
and Van der Waals forces (an additional attractive force between all atoms).
What kinds of patterns tend to form with charged and neutral atoms? How does changing the Van der Waals
attraction or charging the atoms affect the melting and boiling point of the substance?

interactives.title: Charged and Neutral Atoms (conceptual version)
interactives.subtitle: Explore Coulomb and intermolecular attractions.
about: There are two kinds of attractive forces shown in this model: Coulomb forces (the attraction between ions)
and Van der Waals forces (an additional attractive force between all atoms).
What kinds of patterns tend to form with charged and neutral atoms? How does changing the Van der Waals
attraction or charging the atoms affect the melting and boiling point of the substance?

interactives.title: Protein Folding
interactives.subtitle: How do peptides fold into stable conformations?
about: Explore the role of hydrophobic and hydrophilic interactions in protein folding. Generate a random peptide string and watch how it folds in an aqueous environment. Change the solvent to see what happens if the peptide is in an oily environment or a vacuum instead of an aqueous environment.

interactives.subtitle: Testing the Sensor model type

interactives.subtitle: Testing the Signal Generator model type

interactives.subtitle: Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

interactives.subtitle: Body at center is 332,946x mass of orbiting body.

interactives.title: Hydrogen Combustion
interactives.subtitle: The physics in this model will be incomplete until the development of the Chemical Reactions engine.

interactives.title: Ceramic Forces
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the molecular structure of ceramic affects its mechanical properties.
about: This model shows a ceramic (such as pottery or brick), an ionic lattice. In this
model you can use a downward force to bend a small ceramic beam. Use different
amounts of force to bend the beam. What happens to the beam when you use a small
force or a large force? What happens when you release the force?
Compare the structure and behavior of this beam to the metal beam. How do their
behaviors differ and why?

interactives.title: Metal Forces
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the molecular structure of metal affects its mechanical properties.
about: This model shows a metal lattice, such as aluminum or iron. In this model you can use a
downward force to bend a small metal beam. Use different amounts of force to bend the
beam. What happens to the beam when you use a small force or a large force? What happens
when you release the force?
Compare the structure and behavior of this beam to the ceramic beam. How do their
behaviors differ and why?

interactives.title: Plastic Forces
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the molecular structure of plastic affects its mechanical properties.
about: Plastics are polymers, composed of many long molecular chains. In this model you can use a
downward force to bend a small beam of plastic. Use different amounts of force to bend the
beam. What happens to the beam when you use a small force or a large force? What happens
when you release the force?
Compare the structure and behavior of this beam of plastic to the beam of tire rubber.
How do their behaviors differ and why?

interactives.title: Tire Forces
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the molecular structure of tire rubber affects its mechanical properties.
about: Tire rubber is a polymer, composed of many long molecular chains. In this model you can
use a downward force to bend a small beam of tire rubber. Use different amounts of force
to bend the beam. What happens to the beam when you use a small force or a large force?
What happens when you release the force?
Compare the structure and behavior of this beam of tire rubber to the beam of plastic.
How do their behaviors differ and why?
